title: Scarlet fever is on the rise in parts of UK - here is what to look out for
text:

Doctors are urging parents to be vigilant as cases of scarlet fever are rising in parts of the UK. 
Symptoms of the highly infectious illness include a sore throat, headache, high temperature, swollen tongue and distinctive pink rash. 
Official figures show 12 suspected cases have been flagged up this week in Liverpool, twice the number in Manchester and more than double Liverpool’s average cases for the past few months, the Liverpool Echo reports. 
Public Health England experts said they were aware of the recent rises in Merseyside and Cheshire and have warned parents to look out for vital signs. 
There were 10 suspected cases reported across Sefton, Merseyside, last week, compared to around two a week in late December and early January. 
Public Health England recently said Yorkshire and the Humber has one of the highest rates of infection in the UK, according to Hull Daily Mail . Read More Scarlet fever usually follows a sore throat or a skin infection, such as impetigo (Photo: MEN) Signs of scarlet fever on 19-month-old Amelia Russell Jones Duval (Photo: SWNS) Initial symptoms usually include a sore throat, headache and a high temperature (Photo: SWNS) 
A recent report said: "Rates of notified scarlet fever cases so far this season were highest in the East Midlands at 8.6 per 100,000 population, followed by the North West (7.7), Yorkshire & Humber (7.5) and North East (6.9) regions." 
The illness appears to have spread across Merseyside since January, with reported cases entering into double digits. 
But the overall numbers remain relatively low despite the winter increase, with fewer than 100 cases across the area since the year began. 
A Public Health England North West spokeswoman said: “We know that cases have increased in Liverpool and across Merseyside and Cheshire in recent weeks. 
“If parents can keep an eye out for symptoms, that would be incredibly helpful - it is highly infectious. You can find more information on the NHS Choices website .” Like us on Facebook
